title: Naomi Osaka downs world No. 1 Ash Barty in Beijing to win back-to-back titles
text:
Naomi Osaka picked up her third title of the season (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

Naomi Osaka fought back from a set down against world No. 1 Ash Barty to win the China Open and claim back-to-back WTA Tour titles.

Osaka, 21, won on home soil in her birth city that shares her surname in her last outing and made the short hop from Japan to Beijing to pick up her third title of the season.

She has struggled to replicate the form that saw her win the US Open and Australian Open back-to-back for large parts of this season but appears to have returned to those dizzying heights during the Asian swing.

Barty was beaten (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

Osaka came through 3-6 6-3 6-2 after an hour and 50 minutes at the Premier Mandatory event and will climb back to world No. 3 when the rankings are next released on Monday.

‘I mean basically I was telling myself to keep fighting even though my attitude was really trash,’ she said after the match. ‘This was a final, I was privileged to be here in the first place so yeah just keep fighting.’

Both are reigning Grand Slam champions and both have enjoyed lengthy spells at the top of the WTA rankings this season but this was their first meeting since either became a major winner.

It was as tight and tense an encounter one might expect for a clash between two players ranked among the top five in the world but it was full of quality, and an exciting contrast of styles.

Ultimately, Osaka’s serve proved the difference. Aside from one wobble that cost her the first set – broken when serving three double faults – she was largely untouchable – with the crafty French Open champion Barty given a lot more to think about.

Fatigue may have been a factor in the end for the top seed, who saved match point in a draining semi-final against Kiki Bertens on Saturday, and she fell away somewhat in the third set.

The pair are both in contention, along with Karolina Pliskova, for year-end No. 1, which will be decided at the WTA Finals in Shenzhen, but Barty remains in the driving seat despite Osaka’s 10-match winning streak.

Osaka came through (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

After Barty saved a first break point of the match in the fifth game, she drew first blood in a marathon sixth game – one in which Osaka served three double faults – and it proved to be enough to clinch the set.

At the end of the first, Osaka’s coach and father Leonard Francois warned against her getting upset on court and that staying calm was the solution to ‘solving the problem out there’.

Barty went on to save a second break point on her way to establishing a one-set lead, finishing with back-to-back aces.

The third break point – in a third separate game – was the coolest of all. Under immense pressure early in the second set, Barty opted for a high-risk drop-shot, which drifted over gracefully with her opponent stranded at the back of the court.

It was in the sixth game of the second break where Barty finally faltered. She sent a forehand long as Osaka moved 4-2 up.

With the set won and the match level, Osaka, now in the ascendancy, then struck at the start of the third to assume control of the tie.

Barty avoided falling a double break behind by saving another break point but failed to make Osaka pay in the next game, missing a break point chance of her own – the first Osaka had conceded since being broken in the first set – as she sent a forehand long.

The double break did eventually come and she went on to lift a second Premier Mandatory title and her fifth WTA crown in total.

Novak Djokovic reigned supreme in Tokyo (Picture: Getty Images)

In the men’s final in Beijing, Stefanos Tsitsipas will take on Dominic Thiem.

Earlier on Sunday, Novak Djokovic claimed his 76th ATP Tour title, easing past Australia’s John Millman to win the Japan Open.

There were mixed results, meanwhile, for Brits in qualifying for the Shanghai Masters.

Cam Norrie beat Italy’s Thomas Fabbiano 6-4 6-4 to advance to the main draw of the Masters 1000 event but Dan Evans went down in three sets to France’s Jeremy Chardy.

Norrie will join Andy Murray and Kyle Edmund as the Brits in the main draw in Shanghai.
